verses.text: The vision of Obadiah. This is what the Lord GOD says about Edom: We have heard a report from the LORD, and a messenger has been sent among the nations: 'Rise up! Let us rise against her for battle!'
verses.comment: Obadiah's vision focuses on Edom. The reference to a messenger among the nations recalls God's sovereign use of history (see Jer. 49:14; Is. 13:17). The call to battle reflects God's justice carried out through human events.

verses.text: Look, I will make you small among the nations; you will be greatly despised.
verses.comment: The humbling of Edom parallels themes of divine reversal found elsewhere (Jer. 49:15). This reminds us that pride leads to judgment, and true greatness is godly humility—a theme echoed by Jesus (see Lk. 14:11).

verses.text: The pride of your heart has deceived you, you who dwell in the clefts of the rock, whose home is high; you say in your heart, 'Who will bring me down to the ground?'
verses.comment: Edom trusted in its fortress-like cities (Petra). Pride and self-sufficiency blind the heart (Prov. 16:18). The danger of self-reliance over trusting in God is a timeless warning for the People of God.

verses.text: Even if you soar like the eagle, and if your nest is set among the stars, from there I will bring you down,' declares the LORD.
verses.comment: Similar language is used about the fall of Lucifer (Is. 14:13-15)—hinting at the cosmic dimension of pride and downfall. God's dominion reaches all heights and depths.

verses.text: If thieves came to you, if robbers by night—how you would be ruined!—would they not steal only what they wanted? If grape gatherers came to you, would they not leave some gleanings?
verses.comment: Ordinary thieves leave something behind, just as the Law allowed gleanings for the poor (Lev. 19:10). Edom, by contrast, will face total devastation—signifying utter judgment for persistent rebellion.

verses.text: How Esau has been pillaged, his hidden treasures sought out!
verses.comment: Edom is linked with Esau (Gen. 25:23). Their treasures, once their security, are lost—echoing Jesus’ teaching about storing up treasure in heaven (Mt. 6:19-21).

verses.text: All your allies have driven you to the border; those at peace with you have deceived you and prevailed against you; those who eat your bread have set a trap for you. You have no understanding.
verses.comment: Betrayal by close companions (Ps. 41:9) anticipates Christ’s own betrayal. Superficial alliances prove fruitless apart from God’s protection and true unity in faith.

verses.text: 'Will I not on that day,' declares the LORD, 'destroy the wise men out of Edom, and understanding out of Mount Esau?'
verses.comment: Even wisdom is judged by God’s measure (1 Cor. 1:19; Is. 29:14). True wisdom comes from God and is most purely expressed through His revelation—not through mere human cleverness.

verses.text: Your mighty men shall be dismayed, O Teman, so that everyone from Mount Esau will be cut off by slaughter.
verses.comment: Teman, a region of Edom, was famous for strong warriors (Jer. 49:7). Their strength proves vain without righteousness, recalling the superiority of spiritual strength over human power.

verses.text: Because of the violence you did to your brother Jacob, shame shall cover you, and you will be cut off forever.
verses.comment: Edom’s sin is fraternal betrayal. Brotherhood among God's people is sacred, paralleling Jesus’ teaching on loving one another (Jn. 13:34). Division and hatred among believers wounds Christ Himself (cf. Acts 9:4).

verses.text: On the day that you stood aloof, on the day strangers carried away his wealth and foreigners entered his gates and cast lots for Jerusalem, you were like one of them.
verses.comment: Edom’s failure was not only active hostility but also passive complicity. True discipleship means standing with the people of God, especially in times of suffering (cf. Mt. 25:40).

verses.text: But do not gloat over your brother's day, on the day of his disaster; do not rejoice over the people of Judah on the day of their ruin; do not boast in their distress.
verses.comment: Schadenfreude is condemned (Prov. 24:17). Corporate solidarity and empathy within the community of believers is central for true faith and witness.

verses.text: Do not enter the gate of my people on the day of their calamity; do not gloat over their disaster on the day of their calamity; do not loot their wealth on the day of their calamity.
verses.comment: Taking advantage of another's suffering is a deep moral offense. This verse echoes the spiritual principle of solidarity—even in times of divine discipline, God's people are to support one another.

verses.text: Do not stand at the crossroads to cut down those who escape; do not hand over their survivors in the day of distress.
verses.comment: Edom’s actions are charged with cruelty. Christians are called to mercy even toward their enemies (Lk. 6:27-36), reflecting the kindness of our Lord.

verses.text: For the day of the LORD is near for all nations. As you have done, so shall it be done to you; your deeds shall return upon your own head.
verses.comment: Here the message broadens—God’s judgment is universal. The moral law of retribution lies at the heart of divine justice; Jesus affirms this in Matthew 7:2. The day of the LORD points prophetically to final judgment and Christ’s return.

verses.text: For as you have drunk on my holy mountain, all the nations shall continually drink; they shall drink and swallow, and shall be as though they had never been.
verses.comment: The cup of judgment is a recurring image (Jer. 25:15). Drinking on God's mountain originally referenced celebration or desecration; here it forewarns all nations of the ultimate justice God will mete out.

verses.text: But on Mount Zion there will be deliverance, and it will be holy; and the house of Jacob will possess their possessions.
verses.comment: This looks ahead to the restoration of God’s people—'deliverance' anticipates Christ as the ultimate Deliverer (Lk. 1:68-69; Acts 2:21). Holiness and inheritance reflect New Covenant realities, especially in belonging to God’s sanctified people.

verses.text: The house of Jacob shall be a fire, the house of Joseph a flame, and the house of Esau stubble. They will set them on fire and consume them, and there shall be no survivor for the house of Esau—for the LORD has spoken.
verses.comment: Judah (Jacob) and Israel (Joseph) are united in victory—a sign of the restored, united people of God, which the New Testament community fulfills spiritually (Acts 15:16-17).

verses.text: Those of the Negev shall possess Mount Esau, and those of the lowland, the land of the Philistines; they will possess the fields of Ephraim and Samaria, and Benjamin shall possess Gilead.
verses.comment: This lists the full inheritance of God’s people, fulfilling early promises (Gen. 15:18-21). The restoration is total, mirroring the universal scope of Christ’s kingdom in the New Testament.

verses.text: The exiles of this army, the sons of Israel, shall possess the land of the Canaanites as far as Zarephath; and the exiles of Jerusalem who are in Sepharad shall possess the cities of the Negev.
verses.comment: This verse stresses that the scattered people will be gathered and fully restored—a vital promise fulfilled ultimately in Christ's gathering of all nations into one spiritual family (Eph. 2:19).

verses.text: Saviors shall go up to Mount Zion to rule over Mount Esau, and the kingdom shall be the LORD’s.
verses.comment: The deliverers (or 'saviors') foreshadow Christ and His appointed leaders. The Kingdom belonging to the LORD looks ahead to the age when Christ reigns over all (Rev. 11:15). This anticipates perpetual leadership, unity, and the fulfillment of God’s promises in His one holy, apostolic Church.
